DTPR
  • About
  • Vision
  • Tools

About

Digital Transparency in the Public Realm is a project that seeks to facilitate the co-creation of prototypes that can advance digital transparency and enable agency in the world’s public spaces.

The Problem

Technology can help make our roads safer for people, our buildings greener, and our homes healthier. But we need to know its working.

When it comes to performance, even operators aren’t confident the technology is achieving its goal. Whether seeking safety, sustainability, accessibility, or just usefulness, many are left asking: did it work?

New advances have led to new vulnerabilities. This makes it harder for operators of spaces, who now have to deal with new levels of security threats or malfunctioning systems. We’ve also seen that much technology in the built environment lacks controls for people. Our common experience of technology on our devices is that we can install, remove, change, and share what we want. Our physical spaces don’t meet that standard of user-centered design.

Our Mission

Enable human agency in the world's shared spaces.

arrow_forward

5 Principles

Provide transparency

We want to help people increase their awareness of how digital technology in the public realm works and give them avenues to learn more or follow up.

Offer communication and utility

People may want to know about what data is being collected around them, but they also might want to know how to use that data or even to make better use of the environment itself. How might signage be a starting point for helping people better navigate and utilize their surroundings?

Outcomes not outputs

More signs are often not the answer. As visual noise increases, less meaningful information actually gets across. We want to develop a way to know whether signage or channels are working for people; we need that feedback so we can improve the design over time.

Design for adaptation

We know this is just a first take, and we intend for others to build on this work.

Blend digital and physical

We are in a unique position to consider how people move from a digital to a physical medium and back. This transition should feel useful and coherent.

How might users surface information about spaces and systems in a way:
  • That isn’t limited to the visual modality
  • That allows rapid information access
  • That provides different levels of detail based on interest
Conversational UI emerged as a possible solution to addressing the many questions we started with:
  • Support visual, auditory and tactile modalitie
  • Rapidly surface diverse information
  • Can provide links, schematics, or documentation
  • Level of information detail can adapt to user interest

The Solution

We’re working on a standard and some patterns to promote transparency, accountability, and control for people.

arrow_forward

A Vision

Join us on journey that rejects the false dichotomy between privacy & convenience.

Join us on journey that rejects the false dichotomy between privacy & convenience.

your agent

Dock your bike

Arriving at your destination, you dock your bike, and your session is ended. The trip is credited to your monthly membership.

  • The purpose of this system is

    Mobility

  • The service is provided by

    Bikeshare Co.
  • room_service

    The user’s interface is

    Personal AI
  • favorite

    The relationship is

    Membership
